project_templates.tagline: Build an address book with dictionaries!
project_templates.what_kids_build: A contact manager storing names, phones, emails
project_templates.why_exciting: Building a real data management app

phase_1_rule_teaching.intro_hook: Lists are great, but what if you want to store a name WITH a phone number? DICTIONARIES to the rescue!

teaching_script.gigi_says: A DICTIONARY stores key-value pairs. Like a real dictionary: word → definition. Contact: name → phone!

data.code:
contacts = {
    'Alice': '555-1234',
    'Bob': '555-5678',
    'Charlie': '555-9999'
}

print(contacts['Alice'])  # Get Alice's number
contacts['David'] = '555-4321'  # Add new contact
del contacts['Bob']  # Remove Bob

teaching_script.voice_text: Curly braces, key colon value. Access with square brackets. Add by assigning. Delete with del!

rule_card.title: Dictionaries
rule_card.rule: {key: value} stores pairs. dict['key'] gets value. dict['new'] = value adds. del dict['key'] removes.

challenges.prompt: Create a dictionary for one contact with name, phone, and email
Get the phone number from contacts dictionary by name
Ask for name and phone, add to contacts dictionary
challenges.answer:
name = input('Name: ')
phone = input('Phone: ')
contacts[name] = phone

phase_6_complete.celebration: Your contact book works! Dictionaries are powerful!

project_templates.tagline: Save high scores to a file that persists!
project_templates.what_kids_build: A game that saves and loads high scores from file
project_templates.why_exciting: Data that survives closing the program!

phase_1_rule_teaching.intro_hook: What if your high scores SAVED even after closing the program? Files make data PERMANENT!

teaching_script.gigi_says: open() opens a file. 'w' writes, 'r' reads. write() saves text. read() gets it back!

data.code:
# Save high score
with open('highscore.txt', 'w') as file:
    file.write('500')

# Load high score
with open('highscore.txt', 'r') as file:
    score = file.read()
    print('High score: ' + score)

teaching_script.voice_text: With open creates safe file access. W for write, R for read. Write saves, read loads!

rule_card.title: File Handling
rule_card.rule: with open('file', 'w') as f: writes. with open('file', 'r') as f: reads. Always use 'with' for safety!

challenges.prompt: Save the variable 'score' to a file called scores.txt
Load the score from scores.txt into a variable
challenges.answer:
with open('scores.txt', 'r') as file:
    loaded_score = int(file.read())

phase_6_complete.celebration: Your scores save and load! Data persistence mastered!

project_templates.tagline: Build a calculator that handles errors gracefully!
project_templates.what_kids_build: A calculator that doesn't crash on bad input

phase_1_rule_teaching.intro_hook: What if someone types 'abc' instead of a number? Without error handling, your program CRASHES. Let's fix that!

teaching_script.gigi_says: try/except catches errors before they crash your program!
teaching_script.voice_text: Try runs the risky code. Except catches specific errors. Program keeps running instead of crashing!

rule_card.title: Try/Except
rule_card.rule: try: risky code. except ErrorType: handle that error. Multiple excepts for different errors.

challenges.prompt: Wrap input conversion in try/except to catch ValueError

phase_6_complete.celebration: Your calculator is crash-proof! Professional error handling!

project_templates.tagline: Organize code like a pro with modules!
project_templates.what_kids_build: A game split across multiple Python files

phase_1_rule_teaching.intro_hook: Real programs aren't one giant file! They're split into MODULES - separate files that work together!

teaching_script.gigi_says: Put related functions in separate .py files. Import them into main.py!

files.main.py:
from player import create_player, damage

hero = create_player('Knight')
damage(hero, 20)
print(hero['health'])  # 80

teaching_script.voice_text: Player.py has player functions. Main.py imports them. Clean, organized, professional!

rule_card.title: Modules
rule_card.rule: Create filename.py with functions. In main: from filename import function_name
rule_card.example:
# math_helpers.py
def add(a,b): return a+b

# main.py
from math_helpers import add

challenges.prompt: Create a module called helpers.py with a greet(name) function
In main.py, import greet from helpers and use it
challenges.answer:
# main.py
from helpers import greet
print(greet('Player'))

phase_6_complete.celebration: Your code is organized like a pro! Modular programming mastered!

project_templates.tagline: Design and build YOUR dream project!
project_templates.what_kids_build: A project of their choice using all skills
project_templates.why_exciting: Complete creative freedom to build anything

phase_1_rule_teaching.intro_hook: You've learned SO much! Now it's time to plan and build YOUR OWN project from scratch!

teaching_script.gigi_says: Good projects start with PLANNING! What will it do? What features? What code needed?

planning.step1: IDEA: What problem does it solve?
planning.step3: BREAKDOWN: What code for each feature?
planning.step5: TEST: Try it, fix bugs, improve

teaching_script.voice_text: Plan first! Idea, features, code breakdown, build simple first, test and improve!

rule_card.title: Project Planning
rule_card.rule: 1) Define idea 2) List features 3) Break into code tasks 4) Build smallest first 5) Test & iterate
rule_card.example: Start simple, add features one at a time, test after each addition!

phase_3_guided_practice.intro: Choose YOUR project from these ideas or create your own!

challenges.prompt: Write down: 1) Project name 2) What it does 3) Three main features
Code the simplest feature of your project
Add the next feature, test that both work together
Add remaining features, test everything, fix bugs

phase_6_complete.celebration: YOU BUILT YOUR OWN PROJECT FROM SCRATCH! You're a real programmer now!
